mainmatter.p: Given a monad M on a category \mathcal { C }, there is a canonical adjunction between the category of algebras \mathcal { C } ^M and \mathcal { C }. The forgetful functor U_M takes an algebra and forgets the algebra structure. The free functor F_M takes an object X and produces an algebra on MX given by the monad multiplication map \mu : M^2 X \to MX, called the free algebra.

We just have to verify that the two conversions are mutual inverses. In one way, we need to verify \alpha _Y \circ M f \circ \eta = f. This is true because by the naturality of \eta we get M f \circ \eta = \eta \circ f. Then by the definition of algebra \alpha _Y \circ \eta = \operatorname {id}, proving the equality. On the other hand, we need to show \alpha _Y \circ M( \varphi \circ \eta ) = \varphi. This follows from the algebra identity \alpha _Y \circ M \alpha _Y = \alpha _Y \circ \mu and the monad identity \mu \circ M \eta = \operatorname {id}.
Given a monad M : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { C }, an M-algebra is defined as an object X equipped with a morphism \alpha : MX \to X, such that the following two diagrams commute.

mainmatter.p: In an unbiased formulation, we require the natural transformation M^n \to M of the monad evaluated at the object X composed with \alpha : MX \to X to be equal to M^n X \xrightarrow {M^{n-1} \alpha } M^{n-1}X \to \cdots \xrightarrow { \alpha } X.
The algebras of a monad form a category \mathcal { C } ^M, whose morphisms are commutative squares. This is also known as the Eilenbergâ€“Moore category.

A monad on a category \mathcal { C } is a functor M : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { C } equipped with natural transformations \eta : \operatorname {Id} \to M and \mu : M \circ M \to M satisfying identity and associativity laws. In an unbiased way, we have a family of natural transformations M^n \to M with associativity.
In short, it is a monoid in the category of endofunctors equipped with composition as the monoidal product.

An object of the Kleisli category of a monad can be considered as a free algebra, but equipped with a canonical choice of generators. Hence although the Kleisli category is equivalent to the category of free algebras, the objects are essentially different. This manifests as the curious fact that the Kleisli category is not univalent, since an equality of Kleisli objects requires an isomorphism of the generators, but an isomorphism only requires the two free algebras to be isomorphic.

frontmatter.title: The Kleisli category is equivalent to the category of free algebras

mainmatter.p: Given category \mathcal { C }, the Kleisli category of a monad M : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { C } is equivalent to the full subcategory of the M-algebras spanned by the free algebras.
Consider the functor from the Kleisli category to the category of free algebras, sending X to the free algebra on X. This is fully faithful and surjective on objects.
